description: The Islamic State (IS) also known as the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria (ISIS) and The Islamic State in Iraq and the Levant (ISIL) is a Salafi militant organization whose goal is the establishment and expansion of a caliphate. IS has its origins in the early 2000s, when Abu Musab al-Zarqawi began training extremist militants. Zarqawi¬¨√≠s militants became a major participant in the Iraqi insurgency during the American occupation, first under the name Jama¬¨√≠at al-Tawhid wa¬¨√≠al-Jihad and then, after swearing fealty to Al Qaeda, as Al Qaeda in Iraq. Facing backlash from the community and increased security from U.S. and Iraqi forces, the group faced decline until 2011, when it began to grow through its involvement in the Syrian Civil War. In 2013, it changed its name to the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS). Over the course of 2013 and 2014, it quickly took over territory in Syria and Iraq. In addition to its rapid expansion, ISIS has also drawn attention for its public beheadings of Western captives and its large contingent of foreign fighters. On the ground, IS has fought Syrian government forces, Syrian rebel groups, the Iraqi military and militias, and the Kurdish peshmerga. The U.S. began airstrikes against the group in fall 2014.

The Mujahideen Army (MA) is a Sunni Iraqi militant organization that first gained international attention in late 2004. The group is vehemently anti-American and seeks to overthrow the Iraqi government, which it views as an American and Iranian puppet. The group was briefly a member of the Reformation and Jihad Front with Ansar al-Sunnah Sharia and the Islamic Army in Iraq from 2007 to 2008 and has been adamant in it opposition to IS since 2014.

The Islamic Army in Iraq (IAI) is a Sunni Islamist militant organization created in 2003 with the aim of expelling foreign troops from Iraq. From 2003-2011, the group primarily targeted U.S. forces in Iraq, although in 2006 and 2007, several clashes between IAI and Al Qaeda in Iraq (AQI) fighters were reported. The group dissolved itself in 2011 following the U.S. withdrawal in Iraq and its members subsequently created a political activism group called Sunni Popular Movement. The IAI re-activated in December 2013 to fight against the Maliki government alongside many other Sunni insurgent groups. Although it has worked with the Islamic State (IS) since its resurgence in 2013, an IAI spokesman indicated that the partnership is one of convenience and that it may soon dissolve.

Ansar al-Islam (AI) is a predominantly Kurdish Salafist militant organization based in Iraqi Kurdistan. The group was formed in December 2001 by a merger of several other Kurdish Islamist groups. AI had ties with Al Qaeda and fought against secular Kurdish groups as well as the U.S.-led coalition and the Iraqi government. Since 2011, the group has also fought alongside Jabhat al-Nusra and the Islamic Front in Syria. Although it had previously opposed the Islamic State (IS), AI¬¨√≠s leadership announced that the group was disbanding and merging with IS in August 2014. However, the Syrian branch of AI rejected the merger and has continued to operate in Syria as Ansar al-Islam, occasionally clashing with IS as well as the Assad government and other insurgent groups.
state_sponsor_names: Australia, New Zealand, Canada, and the EU; Iran

group_name: Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula
description: Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP) is a Sunni terrorist organization and Al Qaeda affiliate based in Yemen, a country whose geography and tribal social structure are often said to provide an environment friendly to terrorist and militant groups. It was created in 2009 from the merger of the Yemeni and Saudi Arabian branches of Al Qaeda. AQAP has claimed numerous attacks in the country but also targets Westerners abroad. The group is best known internationally for the ¬¨√¨underwear bomber¬¨√Æ who attempted to detonate a bomb on a Detroit-bound airplane in 2009, and for the 2015 Charlie Hebdo attacks in Paris, for which it claimed responsibility. In 2014, it created an offshoot organization called Ansar al-Sharia in Yemen in order to rebrand the AQ name in the country and attract more followers. In 2015, AQAP used the turmoil of the conflict in Yemen to seize territory in the southeast.

Al Qaeda is one of the most powerful terrorist organizations in the world, with a long history and a global reach. It is composed of a core group of operatives and leadership, largely based in Pakistan and Afghanistan, and also maintains relationships with a number of global affiliate organizations. AQ and its affiliates have been responsible for many of the deadliest terrorist attacks in the past twenty-five years.

Al Qaeda is one of the most powerful terrorist organizations in the world, with a long history and a global reach. It is composed of a core group of operatives and leadership, largely based in Pakistan and Afghanistan, and also maintains relationships with a number of global affiliate organizations. AQ and its affiliates have been responsible for many of the deadliest terrorist attacks in the past twenty-five years.
new_description: Al Qaeda is one of the most powerful terrorist organizations in the world, with a long history and a global reach. It is composed of a core group of operatives and leadership, largely based in Pakistan and Afghanistan, and also maintains relationships with a number of global affiliate organizations. AQ and its affiliates have been responsible for many of the deadliest terrorist attacks in the past twenty-five years.

description: Al Qaeda in Yemen (AQY) was the Yemeni affiliate of Al Qaeda, formed in 2000. AQY attacked the Yemeni government and Western targets in the country. In 2009, the group merged with its Saudi counterpart under the umbrella of Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP).

Al Shabaab, meaning "The Youth" in Arabic, is the largest militant organization fighting to oust the Somalian government. The group seeks to control territory within Somalia in order to establish a society based on its rigid interpretation of Shariah law. Although based in Somalia, Al Shabaab also conducts attacks in neighboring countries, such as Kenya. Al Shabaab emerged as an independent organization around December 2006 after breaking away from the Islamic Courts Union (ICU), for which it had served as the military wing. Since the late 2000s, Al Shabaab has had close ties to Al Qaeda and has sought to frame the Somalian struggle as part of a global jihad. The group has engaged in bombings, suicide attacks, and armed assaults, especially against Somalian government targets, non-Christians, private citizens, foreign troops, diplomats, and aid or nongovernmental organization workers.
new_description: Al Shabaab, meaning "The Youth" in Arabic, is the largest militant organization fighting to oust the Somalian government. The group seeks to control territory within Somalia in order to establish an Islamic state. It emerged around December 2006 after breaking away from the Islamic Courts Union (ICU). The group has close ties to Al Qaeda and engaged in a wide variety of bombings, suicide attacks, and armed assaults to achieve its aims.

description: Al Shabaab, meaning "The Youth" in Arabic, is the largest militant organization fighting to oust the Somalian government. The group seeks to control territory within Somalia in order to establish a society based on its rigid interpretation of Shariah law. Although based in Somalia, Al Shabaab also conducts attacks in neighboring countries, such as Kenya. Al Shabaab emerged as an independent organization around December 2006 after breaking away from the Islamic Courts Union (ICU), for which it had served as the military wing. Since the late 2000s, Al Shabaab has had close ties to Al Qaeda and has sought to frame the Somalian struggle as part of a global jihad. The group has engaged in bombings, suicide attacks, and armed assaults, especially against Somalian government targets, non-Christians, private citizens, foreign troops, diplomats, and aid or nongovernmental organization workers.
new_description: Al Shabaab, meaning "The Youth" in Arabic, is the largest militant organization fighting to oust the Somalian government. The group seeks to control territory within Somalia in order to establish an Islamic state. It emerged around December 2006 after breaking away from the Islamic Courts Union (ICU). The group has close ties to Al Qaeda and engaged in a wide variety of bombings, suicide attacks, and armed assaults to achieve its aims.

group_name: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
description: AQIM, originally known as the Salafist Group for Preaching and Combat (GSPC), split from the Armed Islamic Group (GIA), the main Islamist group fighting in the Algerian Civil War, in 1998. In 2006, the GSPC became a formal affiliate of Al Qaeda (AQ) and changed its name to Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb (AQIM). The group is famous for kidnapping westerners for ransom in North Africa and is an active participant in the drug, arms and human trafficking trade in the region. Through these pursuits, AQIM has become one of the wealthiest terrorist organizations in the world.

Lashkar-e-Taiba (LeT) is a Pakistan-based group formed in 1990 that primarily fights Indian control over Jammu and Kashmir. The group subscribes to a strict fundamentalist interpretation of Islam and seeks to establish an Islamic caliphate in South Asia. It has declared the U.S., Israel and India as existential enemies of Islam. LeT has conducted numerous deadly attacks against Indian officials, troops, and civilians in the disputed area of Kashmir as well as throughout India and Afghanistan. The group maintains training camps, facilities, schools, and medical clinics in Pakistan. It runs its own charitable organization, Jamaat-ud-Dawa (JUD), and has supported humanitarian relief missions in Pakistan. In 2002, Pakistan officially banned Lashkar-e-Taiba. In 2008, both the U.S. and the UN placed sanctions on several senior LeT leaders.

Jaish-e-Mohammad (JeM) is a Sunni extremist group based in Pakistan that seeks to annex Indian Administered Kashmir (IAK) to Pakistan and govern Pakistan according to an extreme interpretation of Shariah law. Radical Islamist scholar Masood Azhar founded the group in the early 2000s. Since its formation, the group claimed responsibility for multiple terrorist attacks in IAK, India, and Pakistan, and in 2008 began to refocus its efforts to combat U.S. and Coalition forces in Afghanistan. It regularly targets government and security forces using arms attacks and suicide bombings.

Al Ittihad Al Islamiya (AIAI) formed in Somalia in 1984 with the goal of establishing an Islamic state in East Africa. In the late 1980s, AIAI began to focus on armed resistance against Somalia¬¨√≠s dictator, Siad Barre. AIAI mostly conducted attacks in Somalia, but after Barre¬¨√≠s overthrow in 1991, AIAI allied with the Ogaden National Liberation Front (ONLF), a separatist movement of ethnic Somalis living in Ethiopia¬¨√≠s Ogaden region, to refocus its energy on Ethiopia as its primary target. AIAI¬¨√≠s cooperation with the ONLF and attacks in Ethiopia provoked the Ethiopian government to invade Somalia in 1996 and destroy the AIAI. On January 4, 1997, AIAI announced its transition to a political party, signaling the organization¬¨√≠s effective end as a militant group. AIAI has sometimes been blamed for attacks after 1997, but these attacks were generally conducted by former AIAI members rather than a centralized organization.
new_description: Al Ittihad Al Islamiya (AIAI) formed in Somalia in 1984 with the goal of establishing an Islamic state in East Africa. It helped overthrow Siad Barre in 1991 and then assisted the Ogaden National Liberation Front (ONLF). AIAI's cooperation with the ONLF and attacks in Ethiopia provoked the Ethiopian government to invade Somalia in 1996. In 1997, the group de-militarized.

description: The Tehrik-i-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) is the largest and deadliest militant umbrella organization in Pakistan. The TTP formed under Baitullah Mehsud in 2007. It is a subset of the Pakistani Taliban, which includes most, but not all, of the Pakistani Taliban groups. The organization is closely linked to Al Qaeda, and is also associated with the Afghan Taliban. However, unlike the Afghan Taliban, which focuses on combatting U.S.-led coalition forces in Afghanistan, the TTP focuses on combatting Pakistani security forces. The TTP is based in South Waziristan and has three central goals: to enforce Shariah law in Pakistan; to establish a unified front to combat U.S.-led coalition forces in Afghanistan; and to conduct defensive jihad against Pakistani security forces. Ultimately, the group also seeks to overthrow the Pakistani government and establish an Islamic caliphate in Pakistan. Since 2014, internal splits and Pakistani counterterrorism operations have weakened the TTP. The group remains active under the leadership of Maulana Fazlullah.

The Islamic Courts Union (ICU) originated as a loose association of Islamic courts in Somalia, which provided security and managed crime after the overthrow of Somali dictator Siad Barre in 1991. Around 2000, the courts first united to form what would be called the ICU. The ICU evolved from a judicial system to a governing apparatus, eventually providing social services and implementing Shariah law in the territories under its control. The ICU maintained a powerful militia, which included the group that would be called Al Shabaab, and conquered Mogadishu as well as much of Somalia in June 2006. After ruling for several months, the ICU was defeated in December 2006 by troops from Somalia¬¨√≠s Transitional Federal Government (TFG) and Ethiopia, after which the group disbanded.
new_description: The Islamic Courts Union (ICU) was a loose association of Islamic courts in Somalia, which provided security and managed crime after the overthrow of Somali dictator Siad Barre in 1991. The ICU encompassed, a judicial system, governing apparatus, and a powerful militia. After ruling for several months, the ICU was defeated in December 2006 by troops from Somalia's Transitional Federal Government (TFG) and Ethiopia, after which the group disbanded.
state_sponsor_names: Djibouti, Egypt, Eritrea, Iran, Libya, Syria, and Saudi Arabia

description: Ahlu Sunna Wal Jama (ASWJ) formed in 1991 to protect Sufi Muslims in Somalia. ASWJ was established in response to such groups as Al Ittihad Al Islamiya (AIAI), whose radical Islamist ideology violently opposed Sufism. The group was not a primarily militant organization prior to 2008, instead engaging in community religious affairs. ASWJ began fighting Al Shabaab in 2008 after that organization conducted several anti-Sufi attacks. ASWJ is loosely allied with Somalia¬¨√≠s Transitional Federal Government (TFG) and cooperates with it against Al Shabaab.
new_description: Ahlu Sunna Wal Jama (ASWJ) formed in 1991 to protect Sufi Muslims in Somalia. ASWJ was established in response to such groups as Al Ittihad Al Islamiya (AIAI), whose radical Islamist ideology violently opposed Sufism. The group was not a primarily militant organization prior to 2008, instead engaging in community religious affairs. ASWJ began fighting Al Shabaab in 2008 after that organization conducted several anti-Sufi attacks. ASWJ is loosely allied with Somalia¬¨√≠s Transitional Federal Government (TFG) and cooperates with it against Al Shabaab.

description: Hizbul Islam was an Islamist militant organization based in Somalia. It was formed in opposition to the Somali Transitional Federal Government (TFG) on February 4, 2009, through the merger of four Somali Islamist groups: the Alliance for the Re-liberation of Somalia (ARS), the Ras Kamboni Brigade, Jabhatul Islamiya (Islamic Front), and Anole. Together with Al Shabaab, another Somali Islamist militant organization, Hizbul Islam gained control of all of southern Somalia, various other provinces, and most of Mogadishu in 2009. However, Hizbul Islam and Al Shabaab eventually became rivals, and in 2010, after sustained fighting, Al Shabaab absorbed a weakened Hizbul Islam. Hizbul Islam broke away from Al Shabaab in 2012, and in 2013, the group renounced militant activity.
new_description: Hizbul Islam was an Islamist militant organization based in Somalia. It formed in opposition to the Somali Transitional Federal Government (TFG) on February 4, 2009, through the merger of four Somali Islamist groups: the Alliance for the Re-liberation of Somalia (ARS), the Ras Kamboni Brigade, Jabhatul Islamiya (Islamic Front), and Anole. In coordination with Al Shabaab,  Hizbul Islam gained control of all of southern Somalia, various other provinces, and most of Mogadishu in 2009, before internecine figting broke out. In 2013, the group renounced militant activity.
Notes: best geographic location is southern and central somalia

description: The Moroccan Islamic Combatant Group (GICM) is an Islamic militant group established in the mid- to late-1990's. Like many other armed Islamic movements formed at the time, the GICM was inspired by the mujahideen in Afghanistan, where some of GICM's members fought against the Soviet Union. At one point, the group was considered to have several cells in Europe that financed much of the group's activities in Morocco. The group was founded by a faction split from Morrocan group Shabaab Islamiyah. Despite having participated in several successful attacks, such as the 2003 Casablanca bombings and the 2004 Madrid bombings, the group is now considered to be extremely weak or dissolved. The Moroccan government has conducted a successful counterterrorism campaign that has killed or imprisoned many of the group's leaders. Some believe former members may have simply joined other similar groups.

group_name: Communist Party of the Philippines¬¨√±New People's Army
description: The Communist Party of the Philippines¬¨√±New People¬¨√≠s Army (CPP-NPA) seeks to overthrow the Philippine government in favor of a new state led by the working class and to expel U.S. influence from the Philippines. The Communist Party of the Philippines (CPP) was founded in 1968, and its armed wing, the New People¬¨√≠s Army (NPA), was founded in 1969; because they are so closely intertwined, they are often referred to as the CPP-NPA. The CPP-NPA has historically focused on building support among the rural peasantry, although it has operated throughout the Philippines. While it peaked in size and influence in the 1970s and 1980s, the CPP-NPA still engages in significant levels of violence and is the world¬¨√≠s oldest existing Communist insurgency.
new_description: The Communist Party of the Philippines - New People's Army (CPP-NPA) seeks to overthrow the Philippine government in favor of a new state led by the working class and to expel U.S. influence from the Philippines. Formed in 1968, it has historically focused on building support among the rural peasantry, although it has operated throughout the Philippines. While it peaked in size and influence in the 1970s and 1980s, the CPP-NPA still engages in significant levels of violence and is the world's oldest existing Communist insurgency.
Notes: also operates in Visayas, and Southern Tagalog; EU and Philippines designated

description: The Abu Sayyaf Group (ASG) is an Islamic separatist organization in the Philippines founded by Abdurajak Abubakar Janjalani in 1991. Heavily influenced by Al Qaeda in its early stages, the ASG started as a splinter group of the Moro National Liberation Front (MNLF) and seeks an independent Muslim state in the southern Philippines. In the early 2000s, the ASG attracted attention through high-profile bombings, assassinations, kidnappings, and attacks. It is regarded as the most dangerous group in the Philippines.

The Abu Sayyaf Group (ASG) is an Islamic separatist organization in the Philippines founded by Abdurajak Abubakar Janjalani in 1991. Heavily influenced by Al Qaeda in its early stages, the ASG started as a splinter group of the Moro National Liberation Front (MNLF) and seeks an independent Muslim state in the southern Philippines. In the early 2000s, the ASG attracted attention through high-profile bombings, assassinations, kidnappings, and attacks. It is regarded as the most dangerous group in the Philippines.
new_description: The Abu Sayyaf Group (ASG) is an Islamic separatist organization in the Philippines founded by Abdurajak Abubakar Janjalani in 1991. Heavily influenced by Al Qaeda in its early stages, the ASG started as a splinter group of the Moro National Liberation Front (MNLF) and seeks an independent Muslim state in the southern Philippines. In the early 2000s, the ASG attracted attention through high-profile bombings, assassinations, kidnappings, and attacks. It is regarded as the most dangerous group in the Philippines.
Notes: designated by Australia, New Zealand, and Malaysia; state sponsorship is alleged

description: Lashkar-e-Jhangvi (LeJ) is a militant group in Pakistan most known for its frequent, violent attacks against Shiites in the region. The group is an offshoot of the Deobandi Sunni organization Sipah-i-Sahaba (SiS). Former SiS militants Riaz Basra, Malik Ishaq, and Akram Lahori founded LeJ in 1996 after breaking away from SiS, claiming that SiS had deviated from its founder¬¨√≠s teachings. Since then, LeJ has fueled sectarian violence in the region by killing hundreds of Shiites, while also targeting high-level politicians, other ethnic minorities in the region, and Western interests and influences. LeJ strives to establish a Sunni state in Pakistan and rid the country of Shiite influence.

Harkat-ul-Jihad al-Islami (HuJI) is a Pakistan-based Deobandi militant group with the central aim of liberating Jammu and Kashmir from India and making them part of Pakistan. The group was founded in 1984 during the Soviet-Afghan war and is currently led by Qari Saifullah Akhtar. HuJI has ties to both the Taliban and Al Qaeda, as well as to numerous other Pakistani-based militant organizations. HuJI has been responsible for a number of small and large-scale bombings and assassinations, particularly in the Indo-Pak region, and has an active affiliate in Bangladesh.

Harakat-ul-Mujahedeen (HuM) is a Pakistani militant group that split from Harkat-ul-Jihad-al-Islami (HuJI) in 1985. The group¬¨√≠s main goals are to establish Islamic, Pakistani rule of the disputed Kashmir and Jammu region, carry out attacks against India, and wage war against U.S.-led coalition forces in Afghanistan. To achieve these objectives, HuM employs various methods, including bombings, hijackings, kidnappings and executions of Indian soldiers, government officials, civilians, and foreign tourists. HuM has allegedly received support from Pakistan¬¨√≠s Inter-Services Intelligence (ISI) since its formation. The group is one of the oldest and closest allies of Al Qaeda. It also has links to Hizbul Mujahideen, Lashkar-e-Taiba (LeT), Jaish-e-Muhammad (JeM), Lashkar-e-Jhangvi (LeJ), Sipah e Sahaba Pakistan (SSP), and the religious political party, Jamiat Ulema-e-Islam Samiul Haq (JUI-S). HuM is currently active, and operates primarily in Indian Administered Kashmir.

Jemaah Islamiyah (JI) is an Islamist extremist organization based in Indonesia. The group seeks to establish an Islamic caliphate extending across Southeast Asia. It originated in the late 1980s and was responsible for a number of high-profile attacks that mainly targeted Christians and Western interests throughout the 1990s and early 2000s, including the 2002 Bali nightclub bombings that killed over 200. Following increased security efforts and internal splintering in the mid-2000s, JI has become less active.

Al Jama¬¨√≠a Al-Islamiya is an Egyptian Sunni Islamist movement who seeks to overthrow the Egyptian government and install a Muslim government. The group became active as an umbrella group for student militant groups in Egypt during the 1970s, seeking to restore Islam in the government. The group carried out a major terror campaign in the mid-1990s, killing more than 1,200 people in several major attacks.
state_sponsor_names: There is only a "dummy" profile on the Global AQ map; there is a full profile on our old website.

description: The Moro Islamic Liberation Front (MILF) is the largest militant organization in the Philippines, and it seeks autonomy for Filipino Muslims. The MILF split from the Moro National Liberation Front (MNLF) in 1977, although it was generally inactive and did not call itself the MILF until 1984. The MILF controls territory in the southern Philippines, governing with Shariah law. It has generally focused on political negotiation, but it has a significant history of terrorism and militancy. In 2014, the MILF concluded peace negotiations with the Philippine government for an autonomous region in the southern Philippines, to be called the Bangsamoro. The MILF is in the process of gradual disarmament.
new_description: The Moro Islamic Liberation Front (MILF) is the largest militant organization in the Philippines, and it seeks autonomy for Filipino Muslims. The MILF split from the Moro National Liberation Front (MNLF) in 1977. It controlled territory in the southern Philippines which it governed through Sharia law. In 2014, the MILF concluded peace negotiations with the Philippine government for an autonomous region in the southern Philippines and began to disarm.

description: The Haqqani Network (HN) is a Sunni Islamist militant organization operating in the southeastern region of Afghanistan and the northwestern Federally Administered Tribal Areas in Pakistan. HN was founded by Mujahideen commander Jalaluddin Haqqani in the late 1970s, and rose to prominence in the anti-Soviet war in the 1980s. The core structure of HN is largely familial and hierarchical. HN¬¨√≠s primary goals are to expel foreign forces, increase influence over new territory, and restore Taliban rule. HN employs a variety of tactics including violence, co-option, and infiltration of local security forces and government structures to consolidate its power and support Taliban, Al Qaeda, and other state and non-state actors.

The Taliban (not to be confused with the Tehreek-e-Taliban in Pakistan (TTP)) is a far right Islamist militant organization created in 1994 seeking to establish a strictly Shariah-governed Afghan state. The Taliban achieved this goal in 1996 and ruled Afghanistan through 2001. Since 2001, the Taliban has actively fought to push U.S. and NATO military forces out of Afghanistan and delegitimize the current government of Afghanistan. The Taliban utilizes IEDs, rocket attacks, conventional warfare, unconventional warfare, suicide bombers, mortar strikes, small arms fire, kidnappings, and assassinations to pursue its goals.

The Moro National Liberation Front (MNLF) is an Islamic separatist organization based in the southern Philippines that seeks autonomy for Filipino Muslims, called Moros. The MNLF was established in 1972, and it led the Moro separatist movement until the 1996 Final Peace Agreement between the MNLF and the Philippine government. Since 1996, the MNLF has been surpassed in strength and influence by its rival group, the Moro Islamic Liberation Front (MILF), which began its own peace talks with the Philippine government. Today, the MNLF consists of many factions, some of which support current negotiations between the Philippine government and the MILF.
new_description: The Moro National Liberation Front (MNLF) is an Islamic separatist organization based in the southern Philippines that seeks autonomy for Filipino Muslims, called Moros. The MNLF formed in 1972, and led the Moro separatist movement until the 1996 Final Peace Agreement.

description: Al Qaeda Kurdish Battalions (AQKB) is a Kurdish, Salafi militant organization affiliated with Al Qaeda (AQ) that operates in Iraqi Kurdistan. Since its formation in March 2007, the group has a primarily targeted the Kurdistan Regional Government. However, beginning in April 2014, AQKB may also be engaged fighting the Islamic State (IS).

The Egyptian Islamic Group (EIJ) was a militant Islamist organization founded in 1979 as a splinter of the Muslim Brotherhood. It is most famous for its 1981 assassination of Egyptian President Anwar Sadat and for its close ties to Al Qaeda. The group originated in Egypt, but following a crackdown by the Egyptian government, many of the group¬¨√≠s members emigrated first to Afghanistan, then to Sudan, and eventually back to Afghanistan. Although initially the EIJ sought to overthrow the Egyptian government and establish an Islamic state in its stead, as the EIJ grew more intertwined with Al Qaeda, it reoriented to focus on global Jihad against the West. The EIJ¬¨√≠s most famous leader was Aymenn al-Zawahiri, who became Osama bin Laden¬¨√≠s second in command in Al Qaeda after the EIJ merged into Al Qaeda in 1998.

The Islamic Movement of Uzbekistan (IMU) is an Islamist militant group seeking to overthrow the Uzbek government and install an Islamic, Sharia-driven government. The group operates out of northern Afghanistan, conducting operations in Kyrgyzstan, Uzbekistan, and Tajikistan. With between 500-1000 members, the IMU is closely allied to al-Qaeda and the Taliban, and frequently conducts joint operations with the two organizations. More recent analysis of IMU activity suggests that they are working with groups to overthrow the current government of Pakistan. The IMU has its central bases in Tajikistan and Taliban-controlled parts of northern Afghanistan.

Lashkar-e-Zil (LeZ) is the paramilitary special forces branch of Al Qaeda (AQ). The group was formed in 2002 as a successor to Brigade 055, AQ¬¨√≠s former special operations unit that was shattered in the U.S. invasion of Afghanistan in 2001. LeZ operates in Pakistan and Afghanistan and works closely with many of the other militant organizations in the region, including the Haqqani Network, Tehreek-e-Taliban (TTP), and the Afghani Taliban.

Lashkar-e-Jhangvi Al-Alami is a splinter of Lashkar-e-Jhangvi (LeJ), which is the militant wing of Sipah Sahaba Pakistan (SSP) that has 17 international branches outside Pakistan including in UK and Canada.
state_sponsor_names: No profile for this group.  There is a "dummy" profile on the Global AQ map.

description: 313 Brigade is Al-Qaeda's military arm in Pakistan, made up of Taliban and allied jihadist groups. Members of Laskhar-e-Jhangvi, Harkat-ul-Jihad-al-Islami, Lashkar-e-Taiba, Jaish-e-Mohammed, Jundallah, and several other Pakistani terror groups merged with Al-Qaeda in Pakistan to form 313 Brigade under the leadership of Ilyas Kashmiri.
state_sponsor_names: No profile for this group.  There is a "dummy" profile on the Global AQ map.

description: The Ras Kamboni Brigade was an Islamist militia operating primarily in Jubaland, located in southern Somalia near the border with Kenya. It was founded sometime in the 2000s by Hassan Abdullah Hersi al-Turki, a former leader in an Islamist group called Al Ittihad Al Islamiya (AIAI) and its successor, the Islamic Courts Union (ICU). The Ras Kamboni Brigade fought against Somalia¬¨√≠s Transitional Federal Government (TFG) and foreign troops. In 2009, the group briefly merged with three other Islamist militant groups to form a new organization, Hizbul Islam. However, over the course of late 2009 and early 2010, the Ras Kamboni Brigade broke away from Hizbul Islam. The group split into two factions; one faction, led by al-Turki, joined Al Shabaab, and the other faction formed a new group, the Ras Kamboni Movement.
new_description: The Ras Kamboni Brigade was an Islamist militia operating in southern Somalia that formed in the 2000s by AIAI leader Hassan Abdullah Hersi al-Turki. The Ras Kamboni Brigade fought against Somalia's Transitional Federal Government (TFG) and foreign troops. In 2009, the group briefly merged with three other Islamist militant groups to form a new organization, Hizbul Islam. It eventually split into two factions; one faction, led by al-Turki, joined Al Shabaab, and the other faction formed a new group, the Ras Kamboni Movement.

description: The Ras Kamboni Movement is an Islamist militia based in southern Somalia that emerged as a splinter group of the Ras Kamboni Brigade in 2010. Since its appearance as an independent group, the Ras Kamboni Movement has been led by Ahmed Mohamed Islam, better known as ¬¨√¨Madobe.¬¨√Æ The Ras Kamboni Movement¬¨√≠s main rival is Al Shabaab, another Islamist militant organization in Somalia, and the two groups have fought for control of various areas in southern Somalia, especially the major port city of Kismayo. The Ras Kamboni Movement has held de facto control of Kismayo since 2012, although it has continued to fight other militias seeking to control the city. The group has alternately cooperated with government forces or other militant groups in order to consolidate its rule. It has identified some of its principal goals as expelling Al Shabaab from southern Somalia and maintaining control of Kismayo.
new_description: The Ras Kamboni Movement is an Islamist militia based in southern Somalia that emerged as a splinter group of the Ras Kamboni Brigade in 2010. The Ras Kamboni Movement's main rival is Al Shabaab, and the two groups have fought for control of various areas in southern Somalia, especially the major port city of Kismayo. The Ras Kamboni Movement has held de facto control of Kismayo since 2012, although it has continued to fight other militias seeking to control the city.

description: Hay't Tahrir al-Sham (Tahrir al-Sham), formerly known as Jabhat al-Nusra (Al-Nusra), is a Sunni opposition group that aims to overthrow the Assad Regime and establish an Islamic Emirate in Syria. The group targets the Assad Regime, Shiite forces and U.S backed forces in 11 of Syria¬¨√≠s 13 governorates and has conducted operations in Lebanon¬¨√≠s Bekka Valley. Al-Nusra was formed in late 2011, when Al Qaeda in Iraq (AQI) emir Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi sent AQI operative Abu Muhammad al-Julani to Syria to organize regional jihadist cells. At its inception, Al-Nusra began harboring the Khorasan Group, a cell of approximately two-dozen experienced Al Qaeda (AQ) jihadists who were sent to Syria by central AQ leadership in order to develop international terror plots. However Al-Nusra began targeting the Islamic State (IS, formerly AQI) in January 2014 amid rising tensions between IS and the Sunni opposition forces. Additionally in July 2016, Al-Nusra ended its affiliation with Al Qaeda (AQ) and changed its name to Jabhat Fatah al-Sham (The Front for the Conquest of the Levant). Throughout the conflict, the group has sought to cast itself as an irreplaceable military ally for opposition forces, and has a longstanding military partnership with Ahrar al-Sham.

In 2002, Boko Haram was formed by Mohammad Yusuf as a Sunni Islamist sect that opposed western education and sought to establish an Islamic state in Nigeria. The group has carried out numerous attacks since 2009, including 2011 bombing of the U.N. headquarters in Abuja, but it is best known for the 2014 Chibok schoolgirl kidnapping, when the group abducted over 300 young Nigerian girls from a secular school. Its primary base of operation is northeastern Nigeria, but it has conducted limited operations in Cameroon and Niger. In March 2015, Boko Haram became an affiliate of the Islamic State (IS). In August 2016, IS announced Abu Musab al-Barnawi would assume leadership of Boko Haram. Shekau released statements that Barnawi¬¨√≠s followers were manipulating IS leadership in order to cut him off in a sort of coup; he said that he and his followers would not follow Barnawi, which reportedly led to splits within Boko Haram. It is currently unclear to what extent Shekau or Barnawi has power over Boko Haram militants, but the group remains affiliated with IS.

The Alex Boncayao Brigade (ABB) is a Communist militant organization that emerged in the early 1990s as a splinter group of the Communist Party of the Philippines¬¨√≥New People¬¨√≠s Army (CPP-NPA). It seeks to lead a revolutionary, mass-based movement to oust the Philippine government. The ABB was originally established on April 6, 1986 to serve as the CPP-NPA¬¨√≠s guerilla force in Manila. ABB attacks killed more than two hundred people, including government employees and business owners, between the group¬¨√≠s establishment and its split from the CPP-NPA. In the early 1990s, after a major rift within the CPP-NPA over tactics and ideology, the ABB left its parent organization. In 1997, it allied with the Revolutionary Proletarian Army (RPA), another CPP-NPA splinter group, and formed a political wing called Rebolusyonaryong Partido ng Manggagawa ng Pilipinas (RPM-P). In December 2000, the RPM-P signed a peace agreement with the Philippine government, and it has put forward candidates for elected office. The ABB, in collaboration with the RPA, continues to operate as the RPM-P¬¨√≠s militant wing, although it claims to operate as a self-defense force and to prioritize mass-based politics over armed struggle. The U.S. State Department has included the ABB on its Terrorist Exclusion List since December 2001.
new_description: The Alex Boncayao Brigade (ABB) is a Communist militant organization that emerged in the early 1990s as a splinter group of the CPP-NPA. It seeks to lead a revolutionary, mass-based movement to oust the Philippine government.  In the early 1990s, after a major rift within the CPP-NPA over tactics and ideology, the ABB left its parent organization. In 1997, it allied with the Revolutionary Proletarian Army (RPA), another CPP-NPA splinter group, and formed a political wing called Rebolusyonaryong Partido ng Manggagawa ng Pilipinas (RPM-P). In December 2000, the RPM-P signed a peace agreement with the Philippine government, and it has put forward candidates for elected office. The ABB, in collaboration with the RPA, continues to operate as the RPM-P's armed wing. The U.S. State Department has included the ABB on its Terrorist Exclusion List since December 2001.

description: The Bangsamoro Islamic Freedom Fighters (BIFF), sometimes called the Bangsamoro Islamic Freedom Movement (BIFM), is an Islamic separatist organization based in the southern Philippines. It seeks an independent Islamic state for the Filipino Muslim minority, known as the Moro people, who live primarily in the Philippines¬¨√≠ Mindanao region. The BIFF was founded in 2010 by Ameril Umbra Kato as a splinter group of the Moro Islamic Liberation Front (MILF). It has attacked government forces and civilian targets, especially to undermine peace talks between the MILF and the Philippine government.
new_description: The Bangsamoro Islamic Freedom Fighters (BIFF), sometimes called the Bangsamoro Islamic Freedom Movement (BIFM), is an Islamic separatist organization based in the southern Philippines. It seeks an independent Islamic state in the  Mindanao region. The BIFF was founded in 2010 by Ameril Umbra Kato as a splinter group of the Moro Islamic Liberation Front (MILF). It has attacked government forces and civilian targets, especially to undermine peace talks between the MILF and the Philippine government.

description: The Justice for Islamic Movement (JIM) was founded in November 2013 as a splinter group of the Bangsamoro Islamic Freedom Fighters (BIFF). The JIM seeks to establish an independent state in the southern Philippines governed by Shariah law and exclusively for Filipino Muslims. The group was founded by Mohammad Ali Tambako, who had previously served as the BIFF¬¨√≠s leader, after he left or was ousted from the BIFF in 2013 for conducting an attack on a Christian community. However, Tambako and the BIFF seemingly reconciled soon after the JIM¬¨√≠s establishment, and in 2015, the JIM and the BIFF formally allied themselves to fight against the Philippine government.
new_description: The Justice for Islamic Movement (JIM) was founded in November 2013 as a splinter group of the Bangsamoro Islamic Freedom Fighters (BIFF). The JIM seeks to establish an independent state in the southern Philippines governed by Shariah law and exclusively for Filipino Muslims. The group was founded by Mohammad Ali Tambako, who had previously served as the BIFF's leader, after he left the BIFF in 2013. In 2015, the JIM and the BIFF formally allied themselves to fight against the Philippine government.
Notes: also operates in Pikit, North Cotabato

description: The Revolutionary Proletarian Army (RPA) is a Communist militant organization that emerged in the 1990s as a splinter group of the Communist Party of the Philippines¬¨√≥New People¬¨√≠s Army (CPP-NPA). The RPA was one of several splinter groups formed after a major rift in the early 1990s within the CPP-NPA, which occurred because of disagreements over tactics and ideology. The RPA¬¨√≠s exact origins, goals, and early activities are unclear. In 1997, it allied with the Alex Boncayao Brigade (ABB), another CPP-NPA splinter group, and formed a political wing called Rebolusyonaryong Partido ng Manggagawa ng Pilipinas (RPM-P). In December 2000, the RPM-P signed a peace agreement with the Philippine government, and it has put forward candidates for elected office. The RPA, in collaboration with the ABB, continues to operate as the RPM-P¬¨√≠s militant wing. The name ¬¨√¨RPA-ABB¬¨√Æ is often used to refer to both groups as a single entity because of their close alliance. However, while the ABB has been listed on the U.S. State Department¬¨√≠s Terrorist Exclusion List since December 2001, the RPA has not been included on that list.
new_description: The Revolutionary Proletarian Army (RPA) is a Communist militant organization that emerged in the 1990s as a splinter group of the Communist Party of the Philippines-New People's Army (CPP-NPA). The RPA was one of several splinter groups formed after a major rift in the early 1990s within the CPP-NPA, which occurred because of disagreements over tactics and ideology. The RPA's exact origins, goals, and early activities are unclear. In December 2000, the RPM-P signed a peace agreement with the Philippine government, and it has put forward candidates for elected office.

group_name: The Those Who Sign in Blood Brigade
description: The Those Who Sign in Blood Brigade, also known as Al Mulathamun, was a Salafi-Jihadist militant organization that operated in the Sahel region of North-West Africa. The group was founded in December 2012 when Mokhtar Belmokhtar and his battalion broke away from Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb (AQIM). Despite its split from AQIM, the Those Who Sign in Blood Brigade still swore its allegiance to Al Qaeda (AQ) leader Ayman al-Zawahiri and claimed to act in AQ¬¨√≠s name; however, the group was never formally recognized by AQ. The Those Who Sign in Blood Brigade quickly became known for its large-scale attacks, most notably its January 2013 attack on the In Amenas natural gas facility in Algeria that killed more than 38 civilians. Partially as a result of this attack, the U.S. Department of State designated the Those Who Sign in Blood Brigade as a Foreign Terrorist Organization in 2013. Throughout its history, the Those Who Sign in Blood Brigade often coordinated attacks with the Mouvement pour l¬¨√≠Unification et le Jihad en Afrique de l¬¨√≠Ouest (MUJAO). In August 2013, the Those Who Sign in Blood Brigade merged with MUJAO to form Al Murabitoun.
state_sponsor_names: The profile is Al Mulathamun Battalion.

description: Al Murabitoun, also known as ¬¨√¨The Sentinels,¬¨√Æ was a Salafi-Jihadist militant organization that was formed in August 2013 by the merger of the Mouvement pour l¬¨√≠Unification et le Jihad en Afrique de l¬¨√≠Ouest (MUJAO) and the Those Who Sign in Blood Brigade. The group primarily operated in Mali and pledged allegiance to Al Qaeda (AQ), although the extent of its direct ties to AQ were unclear. ¬¨‚Ä†Al Murabitoun aimed to establish Shariah law in North Africa, as well as to unite Muslims and Islamic movements against secular influences and to attack westerners and western institutions in North Africa. In May 2015, the Emir of Al Murabitoun, Adnan Abu Walid al Sahrawi, swore the group¬¨√≠s loyalty to Islamic State (IS), but shortly after, Mokhtar Belmokhtar, a founder of Al Murabitoun, released statements that the group¬¨√≠s allegiance was with AQ not IS. The U.S. State Department called Al Murabitoun the greatest near-term threat to U.S. interests in North Africa in December 2013. On December 4, 2015 Abdelmalek Droukdel, the leader of AQIM, announced that Al Murabitoun would merge into Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb. ¬¨‚Ä†
state_sponsor_names: UAE, UK, Canada, New Zealand, Australia

group_name: Al Qaeda in the Indian Subcontinent
description: Al Qaeda in the Indian Subcontinent (AQIS) is an Al Qaeda-affiliated terrorist organization founded on September 3, 2014 by Al Qaeda (AQ) leader Aymenn al-Zawahiri. The group is based in Pakistan but has pledged to also carry out operations in Afghanistan, India, Bangladesh and Myanmar. In contrast to AQ leaders¬¨√≠ expectations, AQIS has been largely unsuccessful in carrying out large-scale attacks and has not attracted a significant following outside of Pakistan.

The Russian Imperial Movement (RIM) is an extreme-right, white supremacist militant organization based in St. Petersburg, Russia. Founded in 2002, the group promotes ethnic Russian nationalism, advocates the restoration of Russia¬ís tsarist regime, and seeks to fuel white supremacy extremism in the West. RIM maintains contacts with neo-Nazi and white supremacist groups across Europe and the United States. The group has provided paramilitary training to Russian nationals and members of like-minded organizations from other countries at its facilities in St. Petersburg. Members of RIM¬ís armed wing, the Imperial Legion, have fought alongside pro-Russian separatists in eastern Ukraine and been involved in conflicts in Libya and Syria. In addition to its ultra-nationalist beliefs, RIM is known for its anti-Semitic and anti-Ukrainian views. The U.S. State Department listed RIM as a Specially Designated Global Terrorist (SDGT) in April 2020. It is the first white supremacist group to be designated as a SDGT.
new_description: The Russian Imperial Movement (RIM) is an extreme-right, white supremacist militant organization based in St. Petersburg, Russia. It maintains contacts with neo-Nazi and white supremacist groups across Europe and the United States.  The U.S. State Department listed RIM as a Specially Designated Global Terrorist (SDGT) in April 2020.

description: The National Democratic Party (NPD) is an illiberal, anti-Semitic, white supremacist political party active in Germany. Founded in 1964, the NPD remained marginal in German politics until it began attracting more support in the 2010s.  Though the NPD officially disavows violence, gangs have committed acts of violence in the party¬ís name.  The German government has sought to ban the NPD three times (in 2003, 2013, and 2016) but it remains active.  The NPD campaigns for offices in state, federal, and European Parliament elections but has consistently received low vote shares as it has been forced to compete with the Alternative for Germany (AfD) party.  Between 2014 and 2019, former NPD leader Udo Voigt held a seat in the European Parliament, though he lost it in the 2019 election.  As of 2019, the NPD had 3,600 members, down from 4,000 members the year before.
new_description: The National Democratic Party (NPD) is an illiberal, anti-Semitic, white supremacist political party active in Germany. Founded in 1964, the NPD remained marginal in German politics until it began attracting more support in the 2010s.  Though the NPD officially disavows violence, gangs have committed acts of violence in the party's name.

description: The Traditionalist Workers' Party was a neo-Nazi political party founded by Matthew Heimbach, a leader of the U.S. white supremacist movement and an organizer of the August 2017 "Unite the Right" rally in Charlottesville, Virginia, and his wife¬ís stepfather Matthew Parrott in 2015. TWP promoted white supremacy extremism and advocates for the creation of a homeland for white people in the United States. Though TWP did not promote violence, several of its members, including Heimbach have brawled with protestors.  TWP became defunct in 2018 after Heimbach was arrested for assault against his wife and father-in-law following an affair with his wife¬ís stepmother.
new_description: The Traditionalist Workers' Party was a neo-Nazi, white supremacist political party that advocated for the creation of a homeland for white people in the United States from 2013 to 2018. Its leader, Matthew Heimbach, was an organizer of the August 2017 "Unite the Right" rally in Charlottesville, Virginia and met with European far-right organizations.

description: The Nordic Resistance Movement (NRM) is a Swedish-based neo-Nazi militant organization that seeks to merge all Scandinavian countries into a single nationalist-socialist state. Founded in 1997, the group boasts 250-300 members as of 2017 and has active chapters in Sweden, Finland, and Norway with supporters in Iceland and Denmark.  The Trump administration¬ís 2018 National Counterterrorism Strategy cited NRM as an example of a white supremacist armed group that poses a threat to the United States.
new_description: The Nordic Resistance Movement (NRM) is a Swedish-based neo-Nazi militant organization that seeks to merge all Scandinavian countries into a single nationalist-socialist state. Founded in 1997, the group boasts 250-300 members as of 2017 and has active chapters in Sweden, Finland, and Norway with supporters in Iceland and Denmark.

description: The Atomwaffen Division (AWD) is an accelerationist neo-Nazi militant organization operating in the United States with affiliates overseas. The name ¬ìAtomwaffen¬î is German for ¬ìnuclear weapons.¬î AWD promotes the use of violence to overthrow the U.S. government, foment a race war, and establish a new society based on principles of national socialism and white supremacism. Founded in 2015, the group is known for its anti-Semitic, anti-LGBT, and apocalyptic beliefs. AWD has been linked to acts of violence in the United States, including killings, explosives and firearms offenses, and plots against critical infrastructure. Operating under a decentralized structure, AWD is divided into leaderless cells scattered across the country and has cultivated ties with white supremacist and neo-Nazi groups in Europe. Comprised primarily of young men, AWD was born from an online extreme-right message board and continues to recruit a following on the Internet. AWD¬ís ideology draws from SIEGE, a collection of writings by American neo-Nazi James Mason, a former member of the American Nazi Party, who serves as an advisor to the group. As of early 2020, most of the group¬ís identified leaders have been arrested by U.S. law enforcement. AWD claimed to disband in March 2020 but appears active.
new_description: The Atomwaffen Division (AWD) is an accelerationist neo-Nazi militant organization that operated in the United States with multiple overseas affiliates. AWD promotes the use of violence to overthrow the U.S. government, foment a race war, and establish a new society inspired, in part, by James Mason's SIEGE.

description: Though AWD central in the United States claimed to disband in March 2020, a Russia-based affiliate of the organization emerged in late May of that year. On May 31, 2020, the Atomwaffen Division announced a new branch in Russia and released Russian translations of its ideological texts. The official name of this affiliate is unclear; for ease of reference, this profile has adopted the term ¬ìAWD Russia.¬î AWD Russia launched a Telegram channel and began broadcasting propaganda in Russian, including manifestos from extreme-right terrorists Dylann Roof and Anders Breivik, James Mason¬ís SIEGE, and The Turner Diaries, a foundational anti-Semitic text in the American neo-Nazi movement.  Advertised on AWD Germany¬ís Telegram channel, AWD Russia also maintains a page on the Russian social networking platform VK and solicits applications from prospective members.
new_description: A Russia-based affiliate of AWD emerged in late May 2020 on Telegram and the Russian social networking platform VK. It allegedly receives material support from the Russian Imperial Movement and has encouraged attacks in Ukraine and Russia.

description: A secretive organization called the ¬ìRapeWaffen Division¬î (RWD), organized via a channel on the encrypted messaging app Telegram, claims to be a splinter group of AWD. The group promotes white supremacy extremism, neo-Nazi satanism, and, unsurprisingly, rape against women.  Relative to AWD, RWD adheres more closely to the Order of Nine Angles neo-Nazi satanic philosophy and emphasizes sexual violence more explicitly. RWD boasts of transnational ties to like-minded extremists in Canada, Australia, and Russia. The leader of RWD, who goes by the online names ¬ìSinisterius¬î and ¬ìSinistrovs,¬î is unknown, as is the size of the group. The date of RWD¬ís founding is unclear. The group came to public attention in June 2020 when two U.S. servicemembers, Ohio National Guard Pfc. Shandon Simpson and Pvt. Ethan P. Melzer, were investigated for ties to RWD.  After Melzer¬ís indictment, the group announced that it was disbanding; RWD, however, reportedly has a history of disappearing from public view and returning to operations not long after.
new_description: RapeWaffen Division (RWD) emerged around 2020 on Telegram as an alleged splinter of AWD. The group promotes white supremacy extremism, neo-Nazi satanism, and rape against women. The group rose to prominence in June 2020 when two U.S. servicemembers, Ohio National Guard Pfc. Shandon Simpson and Pvt. Ethan P. Melzer, were investigated for ties to RWD.

description: The Third Path (¬ìDer III. Weg in German,¬î also translated as the "Third Way") is a German extreme-right, anti-Semitic political party. The party has seen little electoral success. Members of the Third Path have conducted patrols of neighborhoods, ostensibly to protect communities against ¬ìcriminal foreigners¬î and have organized collections of food and winter clothing to support exclusively ethnic Germans. In 2019, the Third Path boasted 580 members, up from 530 in 2018.
new_description: The Third Path ("Third Way") is a German extreme-right, anti-Semitic political party, but has seen little electoral success. The Third Path conducts intimidatory patrols of neighborhoods, ostensibly to protect communities and support exclusively ethnic Germans.

description: The Rise Above Movement (RAM), founded in 2017 as the DIY Division, is a white supremacist militant organization based in southern California. With ties to the U.S. skinhead movement, RAM operates essentially as a street-fighting club. Members train in mixed martial arts in order to physically assault their opponents, commonly at political rallies, protests, and demonstrations. The group has cultivated ties with white supremacist groups in the United States and overseas, most notably with the Azov Battalion in Ukraine. RAM considers itself a part of the alt-right and promotes white supremacism, anti-Semitism, and xenophobia.
new_description: The Rise Above Movement (RAM) was a white supremacist mixed martial arts and militant organization from southern California. RAMhas cultivated ties with white supremacist groups in the United States and overseas, most notably with the Azov Battalion in Ukraine.

description: The Hammerskin Nation (HSN) is the largest organization for members of the skinhead movement in the United States. A loose confederation of chapters scattered across the country, HSN began in Dallas, Texas in the 1980s.  White-power music and music festivals play a key role in mobilizing members and consolidating ideology across the various chapters.
new_description: The Hammerskin Nation (HSN) is the largest organization for members of the skinhead movement in the United States. A loose confederation of chapters scattered across the country, HSN began in Dallas, Texas in the 1980s.  White-power music and music festivals play a key role in mobilizing members and consolidating ideology across the various chapters.

description: The Proud Boys (PB) are a U.S. white supremacist, misogynistic, and anti-Muslim extremist group active in the alt-right movement. The organization is known for its participation in demonstrations around the country, such as the August 2017 ¬ìUnite the Right Rally,¬î which the group co-organized.  In 2017, the Proud Boys established a paramilitary wing known as the Fraternal Order of the Alt-Knights (FOAK) with the goal of defending right-wing extremists at rallies. In August 2017, Rewire estimated that the Proud Boys number about 6,000 members online, though the number of active members is unclear. Though the Proud Boys cultivate ties with groups that have neo-Nazi affiliations, PB resists the neo-Nazi label and its connotations for themselves. The group has caught attention for its leading part in the U.S. Capitol riots on January 6, 2021, in which a mob sought to block Joe Biden's presidential election victory.
new_description: The Proud Boys (PB) are a far-right, misogynistic, and anti-Muslim extremist group inside the United States. The organization is known for its participation in demonstrations around the country, such as the Unite the Right Rally and January 6 insurrection.

description: The Azov Battalion is a unit of the Ukrainian National Guard that promotes white supremacy extremism and neo-Nazi beliefs. With the aid of foreign fighters recruited from around the world, Azov has fought against pro-Russian separatists in the eastern half of the country. The group operates a political wing known as the National Corps and cultivates relationships with other extreme-right groups abroad.
new_description: The Azov Regiment is a far-right ultra-nationalist unit of the Ukrainian National Guard. With the aid of foreign fighters recruited from around the world, Azov has fought against pro-Russian separatists in the eastern half of the country. The group operates a political wing known as the National Corps and cultivates relationships with other extreme-right groups abroad.

description: The Sonnenkrieg Division (SKD) is the United Kingdom-based affiliate of the Atomwaffen Division (AWD). The German term ¬ìSonnenkrieg¬î translates to ¬ìsun war¬î or ¬ìsolar war.¬î SKD originated as a splinter group of the System Resistance Network, which is an alias of National Action (NA), a proscribed British neo-Nazi organization. Its ideology includes a fixation on satanism, pedophilia, rape, and other acts of violence. Like AWD, SKD valorizes James Mason¬ís accelerationist philosophy in SIEGE and promotes white supremacy extremism.
new_description: The Sonnenkrieg Division (SKD) is an accelerationist neo-Nazi militant organization and the United Kingdom-based affiliate of the Atomwaffen Division (AWD). SKD originated as a splinter group of the System Resistance Network, which is an alias of National Action (NA), a proscribed British neo-Nazi organization.

description: The Feuerkrieg Division (FKD) is an accelerationist neo-Nazi militant organization that operates internationally as an affiliate of the Atomwaffen Division (AWD). The German term ¬ìFeuerkrieg¬î translates to ¬ìfire war.¬î FKD was founded in October 2018 as an AWD affiliate in Estonia, allegedly by a 13-year-old schoolboy, and quickly expanded overseas. The group reportedly operates mostly online and targets youth and teenagers for radicalization and recruitment. Like AWD, FKS adheres to the "Siege culture" ideology inspired by U.S. neo-Nazi James Mason's calls for a race war. Since its founding, FKD has expanded its operations across Europe and in the United States.
new_description: The Feuerkrieg Division (FKD) is an international, accelerationist, neo-Nazi militant organization that operates internationally as an affiliate of the Atomwaffen Division (AWD). FKD formed in October 2018 in Estonia, allegedly by a 13-year-old schoolboy, and quickly expanded overseas.

description: Atomwaffen Division Deutschland (AWDD, also known as Atomwaffen Division Germany) is the German affiliate of the Atomwaffen Division. The group adheres to a neo-Nazi and anti-Semitic ideology and is known for issuing threats against Muslims and Green Party politicians in Germany. The group's activities are not as publicly known as in the case of AWD central in the United States.
new_description: Atomwaffen Division Deutschland (AWDD, also known as Atomwaffen Division Germany) is the German affiliate of the Atomwaffen Division. The group adheres to a neo-Nazi and anti-Semitic ideology and is known for issuing threats against Muslims and Green Party politicians in Germany. The group's activities are not as publicly known as in the case of AWD central in the United States.

description: The Northern Order is a Canadian white supremacist organization and an affiliate of the Atomwaffen Division. The Northern Order advocates for the establishment of a white ethnostate in British Columbia and allegedly coordinates with the U.S.-based AWD.
new_description: The Northern Order is a Canadian white supremacist organization and an affiliate of the Atomwaffen Division. The Northern Order advocates for the establishment of a white ethnostate in British Columbia and allegedly coordinates with the U.S.-based AWD.

description: The Order of Nine Angles (O9A or ONA) is a satanist neo-Nazi organization active in the United Kingdom. The group valorizes Hitler and champions the transgression of moral norms, including calling for rape and murder. Ultimately, O9A seeks to weaken society and replace it with a new civilization based on principles of fascism and satanism.  O9A practices religious rituals in worship of Hitler and Nazism, which involve sexual acts and sacrifice (human or animal). Founded in the 1970s and originally based in the UK, O9A today operates decentralized networks active around the world.  British far-right extremist David Myatt reportedly started the group. Myatt allegedly leads O9A under the pseudonym Anton Long and writes most of its texts.  Given O9A¬ís secretive nature, accurate size estimates are difficult to assess and range from fewer than 50 members to over 2,000 worldwide.
new_description: The Order of Nine Angles (O9A or ONA) is a satanist neo-Nazi organization active in the United Kingdom. The group valorizes Hitler and champions the transgression of moral norms, including calling for rape and murder. Ultimately, O9A seeks to weaken society and replace it with a new civilization based on principles of fascism and satanism.  O9A practices religious rituals in worship of Hitler and Nazism, which involve sexual acts and sacrifice (human or animal). Founded in the 1970s and originally based in the UK, O9A today operates decentralized networks active around the world.  British far-right extremist David Myatt reportedly started the group. Myatt allegedly leads O9A under the pseudonym Anton Long and writes most of its texts.  Given O9A¬ís secretive nature, accurate size estimates are difficult to assess and range from fewer than 50 members to over 2,000 worldwide.

description: Tempel ov Blood (ToB) is a low-profile U.S.-based affiliate of the Order of Nine Angles (O9A). Though ToB is officially independent from O9A, it derives its satanist neo-Nazi ideology from the British-based group. The group describes itself as ¬ìa hybrid between a traditional satanic coven and a (religious) militant order.¬î  ToB is co-led by Joshua Caleb Sutter and his wife Jillian Hoy, who are based in South Carolina. The couple also operates the extreme-right Martinet Press, which publishes neo-Nazi ideological texts. Its founding date is unknown.
new_description: Tempel ov Blood (ToB) is a low-profile U.S.-based affiliate of the Order of Nine Angles (O9A). Though ToB is officially independent from O9A, it derives its satanist neo-Nazi ideology from the British-based group. The group describes itself as ¬ìa hybrid between a traditional satanic coven and a (religious) militant order.¬î  ToB is co-led by Joshua Caleb Sutter and his wife Jillian Hoy, who are based in South Carolina. The couple also operates the extreme-right Martinet Press, which publishes neo-Nazi ideological texts. Its founding date is unknown.

description: Founded in 2013, National Action (NA) is a secretive neo-Nazi militant organization based in the United Kingdom. The group has also gone by the names Scottish Dawn, System Resistance Network, and NS131.
new_description: Founded in 2013, National Action (NA) is a secretive neo-Nazi militant organization based in the United Kingdom. The group has also gone by the names Scottish Dawn, System Resistance Network, and NS131.

description: The Base is an accelerationist neo-Nazi group operating mostly in the United States and Canada. The group¬ís founder is based in Russia. Organized mostly online as a loose network of cells, the Base anticipates the overthrow of modern society and an ensuing race war. The group¬ís objective is to establish a white ethno-state in North America, inspired by the separatist projects of other U.S. white supremacist groups, such as the Northwest Front and Aryan Nations. As of November 2020, the Base had successfully carried out acts of vandalism, but its major attacks against human targets were foiled by law enforcement. The group regularly holds offline meet-ups and paramilitary training sessions for its members across the United States. Although this organization¬ís name appears to be an English translation of ¬ìAl Qaeda,¬î the Base claims no affiliation with the jihadist group. The FBI infiltrated the Base in 2019 and arrested many of its members between late 2019 and early 2020. In January 2020, it was reported that the Base¬ís founder, a U.S. citizen named Rinaldo Nazzaro, led the group from his residence in St. Petersburg, Russia.
new_description: The Base was an accelerationist neo-Nazi group operating mostly in the United States and Canada. The group's objective was to establish a white ethno-state in North America, but the FBI infiltrated the Base in 2019 and arrested most of its members.

description: The Northwest Front is a U.S. white supremacist group founded by neo-Nazi Harold Covington in 2009. The Northwest Front seeks to bring about the destruction of the U.S. government and establish an independent state for white supremacists in the Pacific Northwest, a goal known as the "Northwest Imperative" or "Northwest Territorial Imperative." In the early 1970s, Covington joined the U.S. Army and later lived in South Africa and Rhodesia (now Zimbabwe) when both countries were governed by racist white-rule regimes.  After Covington¬ís death in 2018, the Southern Poverty Law Center assessed that the group was likely to become defunct.
new_description: The Northwest Front is a U.S. white supremacist group founded by neo-Nazi Harold Covington in 2009. The Northwest Front seeks to bring about the destruction of the U.S. government and establish an independent state for white supremacists in the Pacific Northwest, a goal known as the "Northwest Imperative" or "Northwest Territorial Imperative." In the early 1970s, Covington joined the U.S. Army and later lived in South Africa and Rhodesia (now Zimbabwe) when both countries were governed by racist white-rule regimes.  After Covington¬ís death in 2018, the Southern Poverty Law Center assessed that the group was likely to become defunct.

description: The Fraternal Order of Alt Knights is a violent right-wing group led by white supremacist Kyle Chapman, who uses the alias "Based Stickman." The group was formed as a tactical arm of the Proud Boys and is known for accelerating violence against counterprotestors at right-wing events and rallies. In November 2020, FOAK officially split from the Proud Boys after Chapman was unsuccessful in taking over the group from its current leader, Enrique Tarrio.

description: The Green Brigade was an eco-fascist affiliate of the Base with international membership. Founded as an independent organization in 2019, the group aligned with the Base by 2019 and became defunct in early 2020. The Green Brigade began on Discord, an encrypted online messaging platform, and its founder(s) and leadership are unclear.

description: Oath Keepers is a far-right militant organization operating in the United States. With a focus on recruiting former military and law enforcement personnel, the group seeks to protect Americans from what it perceives as violations of U.S. citizens¬í natural rights by the U.S. federal government. The group¬ís name refers to the oath to ¬ìdefend the Constitution against all enemies, foreign and domestic¬î that is sworn by members of the military and police. Founded in 2009, Oath Keepers (OK) is one of the largest and most prominent organizations of the militia/patriot movement and includes chapters across the country. It is not a white supremacist organization. Members of the group draw heavily on historical memory of the American Revolution, portraying themselves as the heirs of the Founding Fathers and the federal government as a modern-day colonial Great Britain. The group is known for participating in armed standoffs with federal agents in the western United States. In 2016, OK aligned itself with the administration of President Donald Trump and in opposition to the anti-fascist (antifa) movement. OK is politically active, and several members of the organization were elected to public office on the state and local levels. The group played a major role in the storming of the U.S. Capitol on January 6, 2021, to prevent the certification of Joe Biden¬ís victory in the 2020 presidential election.
new_description: Oath Keepers is a far-right militant organization operating in the United States that recruits former military and law enforcement personnel. It aims to protect Americans from perceived federal overreach. The group played a major role in the storming of the U.S. Capitol on January 6, 2021.

description: In early February 2021, the North Carolina chapter of Oath Keepers (OK) split from the national OK organization. Doug Smith, the leader of the chapter, announced that the North Carolina Oath Keepers had voted unanimously to break away; he cited OK¬ís involvement in the storming of the U.S. Capitol on January 6 as the catalyst for the decision. Though North Carolina Oath Keepers had attended President Trump¬ís rally on January 6, Smith said that the chapter did not participate in the Capitol riot. Calling the insurrection ¬ìan ugly stain on our nation¬ís history,¬î Smith said that his group would return to its roots of supporting local law enforcement. According to Smith, North Carolina Oath Keepers had begun distancing itself from national leadership as early as November 2020 due to dissatisfaction with OK¬ís response to the results of the 2020 presidential election. As of March 2021, Smith had not announced a new name for his organization. The founding date of the NC Oath Keepers is unknown; 2018 is an estimate.

description: The Ohio State Regular Militia (OSRM) was an affiliate of Oath Keepers (OK) founded in 2019. Its founder and leader, Jessica Watkins, was a member of OK and claimed that the OSRM has patrolled 12 protests in Ohio and Kentucky since its founding. Watkins allegedly led three members of her militia in traveling from Ohio to Washington D.C. in order to join OK at the riots at the U.S. Capitol on January 6, 2021. In a bid to be released from jail pending trial, Watkins announced in late February 2021 that she was disbanding OSRM.

In a bid to be released from jail pending trial, Watkins announced in late February 2021 that she was disbanding OSRM.

description: The Liberty Watch of Josephine County is an Oath Keepers (OK) splinter group that previously operated as the OK chapter for Josephine County, Oregon, beginning in 2012. The group has also gone by the name Citizen Patriots of Josephine County. In April 2015, this chapter captured national attention when it led militants and anti-government activists from across the United States in an armed patrol of Oregon¬ís Sugar Pine Mine in defiance of Bureau of Land Management regulations. In August 2016, Rice¬ís chapter split from the national Oath Keepers and reorganized as the Citizen Patriots of Josephine County.  By 2017, the group appeared to go by the name Liberty Watch of Josephine County.

description: The Three Percenters (III%ers) is a far-right militant organization founded in 2008 following the election of President Barack Obama. Considered to be one of the largest umbrella groups in the antigovernment movement, also known as the patriot/militia movement, III%ers coalesces around the incorrect notion that only 3% of the population fought against the British in the American Revolution. The group is highly decentralized; some chapters are organized as militias, while others are non-paramilitary in nature or only maintain an online presence. Prominent subgroups affiliated with the III%er brand include the III% Security Force, the III% United Patriots, the American Patriots III%, the III% Originals, and more. On January 6, 2021, the group played an active role in storming the U.S. Capitol to disrupt the formalization of Joe Biden¬ís victory in the 2020 presidential election.
new_description: The Three Percenters (III%ers) is a far-right militant organization founded in 2008 to protest perceived federal government overreach. The group is considered to be one of the largest umbrella groups in the antigovernment extremist movmeent. On January 6, 2021, the group played an active role in storming the U.S. Capitol.

description: Patriot Prayer is a loosely organized, far-right, antigovernment group based in Vancouver, Washington.
